Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Situation2: They organize an intensive workshop for community leaders to deeply understand and apply complex theological concepts.
Story: I sat at my desk, the notes for tomorrow’s workshop spread out before me, but my mind kept drifting to the text from my younger brother. He was upset—again—about something I’d said last week, and he wanted to talk. As his sister, I knew I should call him, listen, and try to clear the air. We’d always promised to be honest with each other, to work through misunderstandings instead of letting them fester. But as a pastor, I was under pressure to finalize my lesson plan for the community leaders’ workshop. The church expected me to guide others in understanding and applying complex theological ideas, and I couldn’t afford to be unprepared. My phone buzzed with another message from my brother, just as an email from the church board popped up, reminding me of the importance of tomorrow’s session. I felt torn—my family needed me to be present and open, but my congregation needed me to be focused and wise. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I stared at the phone, heart pounding, unsure which role to answer first.
